awd_abstract_narration:
There are many questions for linguistic research about the nature of bilingualism, and especially concerning the ways that a bilingual person handles their two languages. It is frequently noticed that bilinguals conversing with each other may rapidly switch between their languages in a system known as "code-switching". Linguistic research has shown that code-switching is actually a sophisticated and rule-governed kind of language use, even though it is often thought of as mixing up languages. It is important to know about the ways that code-switching is constrained so that how our mental linguistic system works is better understood, and so that the linguistic needs of bilingual people are adequately addressed. This research project looks at a special kind of bilingualism, bimodal bilingualism, which occurs when a person knows both a natural sign language such as American Sign Language (ASL), and a spoken language such as English. Bimodal bilinguals also combine their two languages in sophisticated and rule-governed ways, but they have the unique option to use code-blending, the simultaneous production of aspects of speech and sign. This project is an in-depth study of the types of code-blending that are produced and accepted by bimodal bilinguals.

The participants in the project are adults with normal hearing who grew up in households with at least one Deaf parent using sign language - such adults are sometimes known as Codas: children of deaf adults. Participants in our study will include Codas in the U.S., (bilingual in spoken English and American Sign Language or ASL) and Brazil (bilingual in spoken Brazilian Portuguese and Brazilian Sign Language or Libras). As a comparison, some of the studies will involve Deaf native signers to provide a baseline against which the performance of the Codas is measured. Participants will interact with a Coda researcher to produce a variety of different kinds of code-blending. By studying what linguistic structures permit code-blending and which ones do not, the investigators will build a model of bilingualism that should help to explain the types of rules governing code-switching as well as code-blending, leading to an improved understanding of bilingualism.

por.por_cntn:
We have been studying the linguistic structures used by people who have typical hearing but are raised in families with deaf parents who use a sign language, such as American Sign Language (ASL). These people, sometimes known as Codas (this stands for ?Child of Deaf Adults?), often are bimodal bilinguals ? they know both a spoken language (such as English) and a sign language (ASL). We have two main linguistic goals.

 

First, we wanted to see whether Codas, like other linguistic minority groups, have characteristics of heritage language users. When people grow up with a home language that is different from the community language, their home language is called a heritage language, and there are certain characteristics that are often observed for heritage language users. One of these characteristics is that some heritage language users are not as fluent in their heritage language, given that they did not have many peers who used that language. We also found this to be true for the heritage language signers: some of them had high fluency in their home language, but others were limited in various ways. One participant explained that when he signed with his parents, they talked about what they would have for dinner, when it was bedtime, and the like. He therefore did not learn vocabulary about other topics (such as 'community') at home.

 

Our second goal is to better understand one characteristic of bimodal bilinguals, known as code-blending. Bilingual people generally use several bilingual characteristics, including code-switching. Code-switching includes the use of one language in some contexts and another language in other contexts. Code-switching can also involve a switch between one language and another within the same sentence. Some people think that children use code-switching when they haven't fully learned their languages, but actually code-switching is more characteristic of highly proficient bilinguals, and it follows unconscious grammatical rules just like any single language does.

 

For bimodal bilinguals, it is possible to use code-switching between their sign language and their spoken language. However, because it's possible to speak and sign at the sign time, bimodal bilinguals also use code-blending, which is like code-switching but using two languages at the same time. When people who are both bilingual use code- blending, they can produce part of the message in sign, part in speech, and part using both languages - because the person they're with will understand all 3 ways to communicate. We want to understand the unconscious grammatical rules that apply to code-blending.

 

Our research has indeed allowed us to better understand the rules of code-blending. One very important one is that what is expressed in sign and in speech needs to be interpreted as one proposition. People don't say one thing in sign while they're saying something else in speech! Not only do the two modalities, sign and speech, need to be expressing (parts of) one thing, there are also limits on the grammatical combinations that are allowed. The two modalities don't have to be exactly the same. For example, in English adjectives generally go before nouns, such as 'blue eyes'. In ASL, it's possible to have the adjective after the noun, as in EYES BLUE. In code-blending, it's OK to combine the two different orders: 'blue eyes' in English and EYES BLUE in ASL.

 

However, there are limits. We found that it's not possible to produce simultaneously an English sentence in the passive voice ('The dog was bought by the family') and an ASL sentence in the active voice (FAMILY BUY DOG). Our research goals include documenting these kinds of limits and figuring out why they exist.

 

This project has important broader impacts. First, by examining the languages used by minority groups (codas and deaf people), we are able to increase understanding about these groups and increase the breadth of our knowledge about the world. The status of people using a natural sign language can be enhanced by this research. In some cases, this research can also lead to more refined and sensitive expectations about language development that take bimodal bilingualism into account.

 

This project also included substantial training components. The researchers involved in the project included graduate and undergraduate students, who learned more about conducting research and participated in all aspects of the research. The project also included a summer training program specifically aimed at increasing understanding of bimodal bilingualism. The participants in this program, which was conducted in American Sign Language, were almost all deaf or coda. These participants had greatly enhanced training and are on the road to becoming independent scientists. We are proud to report that one of them was awarded an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship.
